title: Unconditional use of `annex.retry` turns error reporting into a mess
body:
Example:

```
git annex copy --to expdir --fast --json --json-error-messages -c annex.retry=3
{"command":"copy","note":"to expdir...","success":false,"input":["123"],"key":"MD5E-s4--ba1f2511fc30423bdbb183fe33f3dd0f","error-messages":["  remote is configured with exporttree=yes; use `git-annex export` to store content on it","  remote is configured with exporttree=yes; use `git-annex export` to store content on it","  remote is configured with exporttree=yes; use `git-annex export` to store content on it","  This could have failed because --fast is enabled."],"file":"123"}
git-annex: copy: 1 failed
```

The command execution fails due to a setup issue (#3127). However, we unconditionally configure any call to `git-annex` to have `annex.retry` set (and we have 3 by default). From the documentation one can guess that this was only meant to be used for data transfer:

```
On transfer failure, annex.retry (sans "datalad.") controls the number of times that git-annex retries. DataLad will call git-annex with annex.retry set to the value here unless the annex.retry is explicitly configured
```

But is presently used for ANY `git-annex` call, unless `annex.retry` is set directly already.

This is not only a UX issue due to error message inflation. Trying 3 times for non data transport related errors is likely also having a performance impact.

This needs to be RF'ed to take `annex.retry` out of `_annex_common_options` and turn into targeted usage for calls where this is actually meaningful.
